Bulky Support.description:
Clefairy is an excellent support Pokemon that utilizes its combination of Friend Guard and Follow Me to support frail partners. Sing is used to disable foes, while After You helps fast teams by letting its allies move before common checks like Calyrex-I in Trick Room. Clefairy can also opt for Heal Pulse to keep its team healthy. This particular EV spread allows Clefairy to almost always survive Mystic Water Urshifu-R's Tera Water-boosted Surging Strikes and cleanly survive Tera Electric Discharge from Choice Specs Miraidon. Tera Grass is preferred to redirect Amoonguss's Spore.

A good partner for Clefairy is Calyrex-S, which appreciated After You to deal with Trick Room and Clefairy's defensive options mitigating its frailty, and helping it set up with Nasty Plot. Clefairy is also a good partner for Restricted Pokemon like Terapagos, Zamazenta, and Calyrex-I, with Follow Me and Friend Guard working in tandem with their naturally high bulk. Checks to Clefairy include Taunt users, notably Tornadus and Incineroar, which completely shut it down. It is also extremely passive, needing strong partners to make up for its passivity.

Ninetales-Alola.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Alolan Ninetales heavily struggles against Gholdengo, being unable to punish it with Encore or threaten it with its STAB moves. Fire-types like Incineroar, Hisuian Arcanine, and Volcarona put pressure on Alolan Ninetales while shrugging off all of its attacks. Opposing weather control like Tyranitar and Torkoal are also major issues, making Alolan Ninetales's Blizzard inaccurate and Aurora Veil useless.
  • Dragonite works well with both sets, providing speed control and taking on the Fire-types Alolan Ninetales is weak to, especially with Stomping Tantrum.
  • Offensive Alolan Ninetales is strongest with other offensive threats to overwhelm the opposing team with Pokemon that cover each other's checks. The most notable of these are Sneasler and Kingambit. Sneasler can threaten Incineroar for a lot of damage and has a faster Fake Out but struggles to damage Dragonite and Gholdengo. Alolan Ninetales can cover for Dragonite and Kingambit can take on Gholdengo.
  • Screens setter Alolan Ninetales works best alongside multiple setup sweepers that can steal the game when supported well. Annihilape and Gholdengo cannot be slowed down by Fake Out and hit the majority of the metagame for great damage. Annihilape and Gholdengo also notably take care of Incineroar and Sneasler, two of Alolan Ninetales's toughest matchups.

Strategy Comments

  • Offensive Alolan Ninetales's primary role is as a fast sweeper with unique support options. It is best when dishing out early damage while being supported by Fake Out or redirection and going down after taking on what it's expected to handle so Alolan Ninetales's teammates can clean up. Screens setter Alolan Ninetales is strongest when it sets up screens for its team and faints soon after, ensuring its teammates can take full advantage of the Aurora Veil turns and being not nearly as passive.
  • Offensive Alolan Ninetales's flexibility allows it to be an excellent lead Pokemon, threatening foes with powerful Blizzards, Icy Wind speed control, and often Aurora Veil support. This lets it adapt in many lead matchups and position itself in a way to win the game. Choice Specs Alolan Ninetales also plays similarly, as its damage output is rather forceful from turn 1. After Alolan Ninetales impacts the game, it's good to send out your other offensive Pokemon that can finish the job most efficiently. Screens setter Alolan Ninetales also finds itself as a lead, but for different reasons. Alolan Ninetales can use its many support options to set the board for sweepers like Gholdengo and Annihilape to come in and set up. Alolan Ninetales may want to Terastallize if opposing Pokemon threaten to KO it before it sets up Aurora Veil or when interested in sticking around for Icy Wind and Encore support.
  • Gholdengo is Alolan Ninetales's most reliable answer, as Alolan Ninetales cannot threaten it or lock it into a move with Encore. Alolan Ninetales is also 4x weak to Make It Rain and weak to Shadow Ball after Terastallizing into a Ghost-type. Tyranitar is also a great counter, overriding weather and passively breaking Alolan Ninetales's Focus Sash. It's wise to use Kingambit and Annihilape to threaten these Pokemon while preserving Alolan Ninetales, by switching it out once its checks enter the field.

Offensive.description:
• Offensive Alolan Ninetales is a good Pokemon in Regulation H thanks to its fast STAB Blizzard in snow, threatening metagame staples like Rillaboom, Dragonite, and the Ursaluna formes, and its ability to support its team in a pinch thanks to its wide supportive movepool.
  • Freeze-Dry grants Alolan Ninetales the ability to threaten Basculegion-M and the plethora of Tera Water Pokemon in the format, such as Gholdengo and Amoonguss. Aurora Veil is a great move to increase the team's longevity when Alolan Ninetales can't do a lot on the field or take advantage of defensive play. Encore can be used over these two to better punish defensive play and discourage Fake Out, especially if Alolan Ninetales does not carry Protect. Moonblast and Dazzling Gleam are great secondary STAB moves on Choice Specs variants, threatening 2HKOs on Kingambit and Annihilape, respectively, and ensuring Alolan Ninetales doesn't get walled by Incineroar. Icy Wind is preferred over Protect to provide Alolan Ninetales with speed control.
  • Focus Sash is preferred to get around Alolan Ninetales's poor defensive typing, Choice Specs and Never-Melt Ice sacrifice longevity for better damage rolls against the metagame; Choice Specs Blizzard OHKOes Ursaluna-B and Never-Melt Ice Blizzard guarantees a 2HKO on uninvested Archaludon not holding an Assault Vest.
  • Alolan Ninetales prefers Tera Ghost across all its sets, as it provides an immunity to Fake Out and sheds all of its weaknesses. Alolan Ninetales can utilize Tera Ice as well, ensuring even Ursaluna gets OHKOed by Choice Specs Alolan Ninetales. Focus Sash and Never-Melt Ice Alolan Ninetales can OHKO uninvested and bulky Ursaluna-B, respectively, with Tera Ice Blizzard.
  • Offensive Alolan Ninetales can provide much more offensive pressure but has longevity issues with the plethora of Fake Out and its weaknesses in the metagame.

Screens Setter.description:
• Alolan Ninetales also finds a good niche as a supportive screens setter thanks to its good Speed tier and access to a variety of other support tools.
  • This Alolan Ninetales focuses more on setting up Aurora Veil and disrupting with Encore so its team can set up and sweep more comfortably rather than threatening bulky Pokemon itself.
  • Covert Cloak is preferred to provide Alolan Ninetales with an immunity to Fake Out and Speed drops from Electabuzz's Electroweb. Light Clay sacrifices this for screens to stay up longer, allowing for more setup opportunities and room to position Alolan Ninetales's teammates.
  • Alolan Ninetales uses Tera Water to improve its defensive profile, turning the glaring Steel- and Fire-type weaknesses into resistances. Light Clay sets may use Tera Ghost to keep the potential Fake Out immunity. Both Tera types remove all of Alolan Ninetales's original weaknesses.
  • The EV spread ensures that Alolan Ninetales survives Sneasler's Tera Stellar Dire Claw and Life Orb Ursaluna-B's Blood Moon. The Speed investment allows Alolan Ninetales to outspeed Indeedee-M and Hisuian Typhlosion, while the Special Attack ensures a 2HKO on Ursaluna-B.
  • Screens setter Alolan Ninetales can last a lot longer on the field to use its support kit, but it is easier to ignore in the majority of matchups due to its lackluster damage output.

Screen Setter.description:
• Moonblast guarantees a 2HKO on Urshifu-R. Helping Hand helps make up for Alolan Ninetales's poor damage output.

  • Light Clay is used to make sure Aurora Veil lasts for the majority of the game.

  • The defensive investment allows Alolan Ninetales to survive Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Moonblast and avoid the 2HKO from Ogerpon-W's Ivy Cudgel and Rillaboom's Wood Hammer, while the Speed investment allows it to outspeed Landorus.

  • Tera Fire allows Alolan Ninetales to resist the Fire- and Steel-type moves that otherwise give it trouble, such as Gholdengo's Make it Rain and Ogerpon-H's STAB moves.

Arcanine-Hisui.overview:
• Hisuian Arcanine is a potent offensive Pokemon on many teams thanks to its good Attack, great STAB coverage, and excellent ability in Intimidate, giving it good matchups against Tornadus, Rillaboom, and Chien-Pao.

  • Hisuian Arcanine works best in Tailwind compositions where its average Speed and poor defensive typing don't often hold it back, hence why Tailwind setters like Tornadus make good partners. In return, Hisuian Arcanine can provide Tornadus with Intimidate support, letting it stick around longer and support it with Tailwind or Bleakwind Storm damage.

  • Hisuian Arcanine can be severely overwhelmed by Pokemon like Urshifu-R and Landorus, making Pokemon like Rillaboom and Latias good partners. Hisuian Arcanine also can be hindered heavily by other Intimidate users like Incineroar, meaning it appreciates having Pokemon like Landorus that can threaten it.

Choice Band.description:
• Tera Blast Fairy can hit foes like Urshifu-R, Urshifu, and Raging Bolt, the former of which walls Hisuian Arcanine's STABs. Head Smash can be used to threaten Pokemon like Incineroar and Ogerpon-W with an OHKO at the cost of being chipped down by recoil.

  • Choice Band boosts Hisuian Arcanine's damage, allowing for OHKOs on top threats like Urshifu-R, Kingambit, and Ogerpon-H.

  • The given EV spread lets Hisuian Arcanine take two unboosted Flutter Mane Shadow Balls and almost always survive a Stomping Tantrum from Ogerpon-H. The Speed EVs let it outspeed Regieleki in Tailwind.

  • Tera Fairy lets Hisuian Arcanine remove its weakness to Fighting-type attacks, which can be useful in a pinch against Chien-Pao; this can also let it survive Surging Strikes from Mystic Water Urshifu-R. Tera Normal boosts Extreme Speed's damage, which can be helpful against neutral targets like Urshifu-R.

Bulky Support.description:
Galarian Weezing benefits its allies by disabling almost all abilities with Neutralizing Gas and spreading poison. It can be used with Pokemon with abilities that cannot be disabled like Calyrex-S and Pokemon with abilities that are not always necessary for them to function such as Iron Hands and Roaring Moon. It works best against Pokemon with abilities that are important to their performance, such as Prankster Whimsicott and Tornadus, and those that boost their damage and set up Terrain or weather to help their team, such as Miraidon, Koraidon, and Kyogre. Dazzling Gleam can be used for reliable damage and to break Focus Sashes while ignoring redirection, but Strange Steam can be used for a higher chance to OHKO Roaring Moon and Koraidon. Toxic Spikes is used to wear down foes over time, allowing Galarian Weezing's partners to easily clean up late-game. Additionally, it works well against teams without a grounded Poison-type like Amoonguss to absorb Toxic Spikes. Poison Gas is best against Pokemon that intend to set up and stay on the field for a while, such as Calm Mind Terapagos, especially since it is a spread move and cannot be redirected, though it can be blocked by Wide Guard. Protect can bait out Fake Out if Covert Cloak is not being used and can stall turns to rack up poison damage. Covert Cloak can ensure Toxic Spikes is set up against Fake Out users, Sitrus Berry improves survivability, and Mental Herb stops Taunt and Encore from disrupting Toxic Spikes and Poison Gas setup. 12 Speed EVs is used to outspeed Farigiraf and Incineroar with low Speed investment. The EVs in Special Defense allow survival of Astral Barrage from Choice Specs Calyrex-S and Water Spout from Mystic Water Kyogre, given that rain is not active. The defensive investment allows for a high chance to survive Precipice Blades from Groudon and guaranteed survival of Surging Strikes from Urshifu-R. Tera Dark gives Galarian Weezing a resistance to Calyrex-S’s STAB attacks. Tera Grass grants an immunity to Spore and turns its weakness to Ground-type attacks such as Landorus-I's Earth Power into a resistance as well as granting a resistance to Electric-type attacks like Electro Drift from Miraidon. Tera Water grants a resistance to Glacial Lance from Calyrex-I.

Faster Taunt users such as Whimsicott shut down the status options of Galarian Weezing without Mental Herb, and sets without Sitrus Berry are vulnerable to high damage from double targeting. Poison-types such as Amoonguss wall Galarian Weezing and absorb Toxic Spikes, preventing it from inflicting poison. Since Galarian Weezing typically cannot deal immediate damage, it relies on its teammates to win games, and it will often lose late-game against offensive Pokemon. Galarian Weezing is often partnered with Calyrex-S because its As One ability is unaffected by Neutralizing Gas. Additionally, Galarian Weezing is commonly paired with Dondozo and Tatsugiri, as a Commander-boosted Dondozo can sweep teams that have been weakened by poison damage, and it can effectively stall out poison damage by using Protect and recovering from Leftovers. Fighting-type teammates like Urshifu-R and Iron Hands can take advantage of Terapagos's Tera Shell being disabled to OHKO it with Close Combat. Indeedee-F supports these teams by providing redirection and providing Psychic-type offense on its own. Ogerpon-C can use Follow Me to guarantee Galarian Weezing's Toxic Spikes setup. Roaring Moon can threaten Psychic-types with Knock Off and provide Tailwind for the team.

Trick Room Support.description:
Electabuzz is a good Trick Room support Pokemon that uses redirection and disruption, being able to threaten one of the most popular Pokemon in Amoonguss by shutting it down with Taunt and redirecting Spore while also taking hits from threats such as Miraidon. Follow Me is able to redirect powerful attacks like Electro Drift from Miraidon and Body Press from Zamazenta-C away from allies, and Volt Switch can get Electabuzz out of a sticky matchup while also getting in a powerful Trick Room attacker. Taunt stops Pokemon like Amoonguss and Clefairy from disrupting the rest of the team as well as stopping Incineroar from using Taunt or Will-O-Wisp. Feint is able to break Wide Guard and Protect for powerful allies like Calyrex-I while also denying a double Protect, which can stall Trick Room. The EV spread allows Electabuzz to survive a +2 Spell Tag Calyrex-S Astral Barrage or a +3 Zamazenta-C Body Press. Tera Ghost is used to avoid Fake Out, as well as strengthen the matchup against Zamazenta-C and Iron Hands.

Electabuzz tends to struggle with its damage output, applying no real damage pressure. Offensive Ground-types such as Ursaluna-B and Landorus can also be problems. Calyrex-I is an amazing partner, making up for Electabuzz's passive nature and threatening the aforementioned Ground-types that give Electabuzz trouble; in return, Calyrex-I appreciates that Electabuzz can redirect Spore from Amoonguss and keep Calyrex-I healthy with Follow Me and deny Taunt and Will-O-Wisp from Incineroar with its own Taunt. Ursaluna-B is a good partner, as it also deals immense damage while also appreciating the support into Amoonguss. Electabuzz also helps Ursaluna-B by redirecting attacks like Close Combat from the Urshifu formes and Body Press from Zamazenta-C.

Support.description:
• Electabuzz works as a good bulky redirector that can redirect away sleep in Spore and Dire Claw while denying Trick Room with Taunt and slowing opposing Pokemon down, utilizing its good Speed.

  • Electroweb can do decent chip damage while providing speed control, slowing down threats such as Rillaboom and Dragonite. Taunt can deny redirection from Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Clefable, but more importantly, Taunt can shut down Trick Room from Pokemon such as Porygon2 and Indeedee-F.

  • Eviolite grants immense bulk to Electabuzz, allowing it to redirect more attacks and support for longer.

  • Tera Ghost provides an immunity to Fake Out, removing a potential hindrance to its support. Tera Ghost also shuts down Sneasler but makes Electabuzz weak to Kingambit and Basculegion. Tera Fairy leaves Electabuzz not weak to most of the metagame's attacks and helps into Kingambit that aren't using Iron Head, as well as the many Dragon-type Pokemon in the format like Dragapult and Dragonite, at the cost of being weak to Gholdengo and Sneasler.

  • The Defense investment lets Electabuzz take Guts-boosted Headlong Rush from Ursaluna after it Terastallizes while also surviving Stomping Tantrum from Life Orb Garchomp. The Special Defense investment lives a +2 Draco Meteor from Archaludon as well as easily taking a Choice Specs Shadow Ball from Gholdengo. The Speed outspeeds Timid Pelipper.

Magmar.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Since Magmar’s primary role is redirection, it pairs best with teammates that can either apply immediate offensive pressure or set up for a potential sweep. Although there are other popular teammates like Gholdengo and Dragonite that work well with it, Magmar has been used mainly on a specific balance composition, consisting of Kingambit, Rillaboom, Sneasler, Primarina, and Dragapult to round out the Fire / Water / Grass core.
  • Kingambit is a great partner for Magmar because it can set up safely with Swords Dance and exert significant offensive pressure. Plus, with priority Sucker Punch, Magmar realistically only needs to buy Kingambit one turn. Similarly, Gholdengo is another great partner for it, safely stacking Nasty Plot boosts and sweeping with Make It Rain. Additionally, Magmar can redirect potential Sucker Punch from an opposing Kingambit and burn it with Will-O-Wisp so Gholdengo doesn't outright lose to Kingambit.
  • Rillaboom synergizes with Magmar by providing coverage for common Water-types like Primarina and Basculegion-M and Ground-types like Ursaluna-B that threaten Magmar. In return, Magmar redirects attacks that threaten Rillaboom, most importantly Dire Claw from Sneasler.
  • Primarina works well with Magmar, as it will safely chip away at foes with Hyper Voice without worrying about Dire Claw, Wood Hammer, or Spore from Sneasler, Rillaboom, and Amoonguss. Magmar also pressures Steel-types like Gholdengo and Assault Vest Kingambit that Primarina has a hard time against.
  • Sneasler puts pressure on many relevant Pokemon, including those that Magmar struggles against, like Archaludon and Primarina. Magmar supports Sneasler by helping it maintain its Focus Sash for longer and focus on its role as a glass cannon. Also acting as a glass cannon, Dragapult appreciates redirection, which allows it to safely spam Dragon Darts and deal large amounts of chip damage to both foes.

Strategy Comments

  • Magmar's playstyle is straightforward; it enables its teammates to secure KOs while it tanks the hits. For balance compositions, it's the defensive backbone of the team.
  • Typically, Magmar is better as a lead to safely establish early-game offensive dominance with glass cannons like Sneasler and Dragapult or setup sweepers like Swords Dance Kingambit. Once Magmar has fainted and momentum has been established, you can bring in another offensive threat and clean up.
  • One of the biggest flaws of Magmar is spread damage. While this largely can't be avoided, some of the common spread moves can be mitigated with the proper positioning. For example, Expanding Force in Psychic Terrain can be made single target by a well-timed Rillaboom swap, and Eruption from Hisuian Typhlosion can be tanked well by Primarina, which can dish back solid damage. Magmar also struggles against standard Archaludon rain teams. To deal with this, Sneasler, Rillaboom, and Kingambit are solid choices. Sneasler threatens Archaludon with its STAB attacks even if Archaludon Terastallizes, while Rillaboom can handle Basculegion-M effectively. Kingambit pressures everything with boosted Sucker Punch, especially Archaludon before it accumulates too many Stamina boosts.

Bulky Redirector.description:
• Magmar’s role is to redirect attacks with Follow Me, allowing its teammates to set up or attack safely.
  • Vital Spirit lets Magmar redirect status moves like Spore and Sleep Powder from Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Vivillon without being put to sleep. Flame Body can punish certain physical attackers like Rillaboom, Sneasler, and Kingambit by redirecting their attacks and potentially burning them.
  • Overheat is used for a large burst of damage, while Heat Wave is sometimes preferred for its consistency, providing spread chip damage without the Special Attack drop. Will-O-Wisp is useful for pressuring physical attackers like Sneasler and Dragonite as well as physical setup threats like Kingambit. Clear Smog can be useful for hindering certain setup Pokemon like Quiver Dance Volcarona.
  • Tera Ghost, especially when Magmar's teammate can't use Protect, is particularly helpful for gaining a Fake Out immunity to allow it to click Follow Me.
  • The Defense investment lets Magmar comfortably take a Stomping Tantrum from Life Orb Garchomp, withstand two hits from Tera Dragon Dragon Darts from Choice Band Dragapult, and nearly always survive Population Bomb from Maushold. The Special Defense investment allows it to take Weather Ball from Timid Pelipper.

Choice Scarf.description:
Ditto is used for its phenomenal ability to transform into strong opposing Pokemon, which is invaluable in a format with Restricted Pokemon, giving you access to an extra extremely powerful Pokemon. Ditto is a good late-game cleaner that likes copying Pokemon such as Calyrex-S and Miraidon, since it outspeeds and threatens an OHKO onto both of them. Choice Scarf is used to allow Ditto to outspeed the Pokemon it transforms into, giving Ditto the advantage while fighting it. Tera Ghost is used to give Ditto an immunity to Fake Out, which can severely hinder its momentum.

Terapagos can be an issue for Ditto, since if Terapagos Terastallizes, Imposter will not work, and Terapagos will OHKO it. Ditto also struggles with Pokemon that can slow its momentum, such as Rillaboom and Incineroar with the aforementioned Fake Out and Amoonguss with Spore and Rage Powder. Fighting-types, such as Iron Hands and the Urshifu formes, can help against Incineroar and Terapagos, and Ice-types, such as Chien-Pao and Calyrex-I, can help against Amoonguss and Rillaboom. Incineroar and Amoonguss are also good partners for Ditto, as they help it get attacks off with Spore, Rage Powder, and Fake Out support. The aforementioned Urshifu-R, Iron Hands, and Incineroar can help Ditto position itself and transform into the ideal foe with U-Turn, Volt Switch, and Parting Shot respectively.

Articuno.overview:
• Articuno has a unique niche in the metagame thanks strong Ice-type STAB attacks and great bulk. Blizzard allows Articuno to tear through common cores utilizing Rillaboom, Landorus, and Raging Bolt.

  • Alolan Ninetales is mandatory with Articuno, patching up Blizzard's accuracy and amplifying its bulk and damage output through snow, Aurora Veil, and Helping Hand. Landorus makes for a great offensive partner, threatening Ice-resistant foes like Incineroar, Gholdengo, and Kingambit. Articuno is capable of removing Ground-immune foes like Dragonite and opposing Landorus in return.

  • Articuno's lack of coverage means the aforementioned Ice-resistant Pokemon such as Incineroar, Gholdengo, and Kingambit are problematic. Opposing weather from setters like Sunny Day and Rain Dance Tornadus are also an issue, as Articuno becomes a lot easier to remove without the added bulk and accurate Blizzards.

Choice Specs.description:
• Blizzard is used as Articuno's primary Ice-type STAB move, as it threatens both foes. Ice Beam is used for a strong single-target attack, and Freeze-Dry is chosen to threaten Water-types like Ogerpon-W, Urshifu-R, and Terastallized Amoonguss, which otherwise take it's hits exceptionally well. Sheer Cold is preferred in the last moveslot to threaten bulky Ice-resistant foes such as Incineroar, Dondozo, and Kingambit.

  • Choice Specs allows Articuno to 2HKO Flutter Mane and Terastallized Ogerpon-W with Ice Beam and Freeze-Dry, respectively.

  • The given EV spread lets Articuno almost always avoid the 2HKO from Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Tera Fairy Dazzling Gleam and almost always survive Ogerpon-H's Tera Fire Ivy Cudgel under snow and Aurora Veil.

  • Articuno utilizes Tera Ice to shed its weakness to Raging Bolt's Thunderclap and keep the Defense boost from snow as well as make up for its mediocre damage output. This is because snow and Aurora Veil allow Articuno to function in seemingly bad matchups without a defensive Tera type.

Black Glasses.description:
Galarian Moltres utilizes its great bulk, typing, and movepool to become a great offensive support Pokemon that can also beat the powerful Calyrex formes. Fiery Wrath provides a consistent spread STAB option paired with its chance to flinch, complimenting Galarian Moltres's bulk as a great tool to rack up damage. Foul Play on the other hand is a great anti-physical attacker tool, giving Galarian Moltres a fairly good matchup into Calyrex-I. Tailwind gives Galarian Moltres a supportive role in providing speed control for its team, allowing it to outspeed and fire off Fiery Wraths and Foul Plays. Black Glasses helps boost Galarian Moltres's damage output even more, allowing it to OHKO Calyrex-S and pairing well with potential Berserk boosts. The Speed investment allows Galarian Moltres to outspeed Choice Scarf Urshifu-R with Tailwind active, as well as naturally outspeeding most Gholdengo. The defensive investment allows Galarian Moltres to have a good chance of surviving a +2 Tera Fairy-boosted Draining Kiss from Calyrex-S or a Flare Blitz from non-Tera Fire Koraidon. Tera Dark sheds Galarian Moltres's Ice and Electric weaknesses, and the increased damage to its Dark-type STAB moves allow it to threaten an OHKO on Calyrex-I.

Galarian Moltres typically struggles against Pokemon that can reliably win the damage trade versus it like Raging Bolt and Zamazenta-C. Amoonguss is able to comfortably tank Galarian Moltres's attacks and retaliate with Spore. Miraidon and Urshifu-R are also problematic matchups for Galarian Moltres, as Miraidon is able to outspeed and OHKO it, while Urshifu-R takes minimal damage from Galarian Moltres and can hit it in return with a Surging Strikes. While Zamazenta-C is is a great check against Galarian Moltres, it is also an amazing partner. Galarian Moltres gives it speed control and strong super effective damage against the Ghost-types Zamazenta-C would typically struggle against while Zamazenta-C grants Wide Guard support for Galarian Moltres, allowing it to effectively counter Calyrex-I. Fairy-types that would try to counter Galarian Moltres like Flutter Mane and Tera Fairy Calyrex-S are also covered by Zamazenta-C's Heavy Slam. Rillaboom is able to deal with opposing Urshifu-R trying to take advantage of their Dark resistance, as well as overriding Electric Terrain from Miraidon and threatening an OHKO with Choice Band-boosted High Horsepower.

Dragonite.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Dragonite is a very common bulky physical attacker on balance and physically offensive Coaching teams. Dragonite shines particularly well against weakened teams. It also appreciates redirection or speed control to make up for its mediocre Speed. It works well at supporting teams against hyper offensive teams, with its Multiscale sets allowing it to survive attacks from many common wallbreakers, including Garchomp and Kingambit. Dragonite works well on balance teams, which value more the great consistency and versatility in matchups and the support it can provide to the team through Haze and Tailwind.
  • Dragonite works very well in tandem with Gholdengo and Kingambit, which can cover the Fairy- and Ice-types that may threaten Dragonite. Dragonite also appreciates Coaching support from partners such as Sneasler, which can allow it to mitigate Defense drops from Scale Shot and become difficult to remove for many teams with just a few Coaching boosts. Additionally, redirection from Amoonguss and Fake Out from Rillaboom and Incineroar allow it to better fulfill both its offensive and supportive roles on a team.
  • Dragonite's main issues are its relatively low Speed, weakness to Intimidate, and inability to hit Fairy- and Steel-types except with relatively weak coverage options. Therefore, partners like Kingambit and Sneasler can help hit Dragonite's checks heavily. Additionally, Coaching can help shore up its lesser damage output, particularly against Intimidate from Incineroar, and Defiant from the aforementioned Kingambit as well as Annihilape can help punish Intimidate cycling. Another issue for Dragonite are Pokemon that are faster than it and can threaten to OHKO it, such as Dragapult, Alolan Ninetales, and Garchomp. Therefore, redirection is of great use to these Dragonite sets to deal with such threats.

Strategy Comments

  • Dragonite's main role on teams is as a bulky attacker that can also provide support for its team through Haze and Tailwind. It uses its power and priority to clean up weakened teams while maintaining usefulness throughout the game.
  • Dragonite is best used for its heavy damage output and large bulk, so it must be positioned it carefully around potential threats. Dragonite is at its best when Multiscale is kept intact, so keeping it away from weak attacks that may break it is crucial, as having Multiscale can allow Dragonite to tank a powerful hit from a threatening Pokemon and KO back. It can be used as a strong lead into offensive strategies or as a late-game cleaner against more balanced teams. It can also provide important support for its team if it is running Tailwind.
  • Dragonite's biggest issues are against Steel-types that are capable of withstanding its coverage options, such as Gholdengo and Corviknight, and strong Fairy- and Ice-types like Alolan Ninetales. To mitigate these threats, position your other Pokemon that can handle them and hit them with heavy damage early in the game with partners such as Sneasler and Incineroar so Dragonite can pick them off later in the game once correctly positioned. Another way around these threats is with redirection to protect Dragonite or Coaching support so it can overpower its checks.

Bulky Attacker.description:
• Dragonite uses its high Attack and strong defenses, which are further boosted by Multiscale, to be a very powerful bulky physical attacker. It can be used to check a variety of metagame threats, including Sneasler, Rillaboom, and Torkoal, and provide support for itself and its teammates through the likes of Tailwind and Haze.

  • Scale Shot gives Dragonite a consistent and powerful STAB option, and the Speed boost gives it the potential to sweep teams. Tailwind allows Dragonite to support its team through speed control. Extreme Speed gives Dragonite a strong priority option to finish off low HP foes. Additionally, Haze can be used to counter setup sweepers like Dondozo. Ice Spinner provides coverage for Dragon-types with a 4x weakness to Ice such as Garchomp and can be used to clear Terrains, namely Psychic Terrain, from the field, whereas Stomping Tantrum gives it coverage for Steel- and Fire-types such as Kingambit and Incineroar.

  • Tera Fairy gives Dragonite an important immunity to Dragon-type moves, particularly Scale Shot from opposing Dragonite, giving it strong defensive utility and the ability to check powerful Dragons like Garchomp while removing Dragonite's Fairy and Ice weaknesses. Fairy is also a good defensive typing, being neutral or resistant to the majority of metagame-relevant attacks. However, this Tera type can leave it vulnerable to other important attacks, including Dire Claw from Sneasler and Make It Rain from Gholdengo. Tera Steel gives Dragonite a resistance to Ice-, Dragon- and Fairy-type attacks, including Blizzard from Alolan Ninetales, Moonblast from Primarina, and Dragon Claw from Garchomp that threaten it, while providing an immunity to Sneasler's Dire Claw and a resistance to Gholdengo's Make It Rain. This Tera type can also make it vulnerable to Ground-, Fire- and Fighting-type attacks.

  • 52 Speed EVs with an Adamant Nature allow Dragonite to outspeed Dragapult under Tailwind while allowing it to naturally outspeed Rillaboom and Archaludon and Ursaluna-B with low Speed investment while maximizing its damage output and maintaining its massive bulk. This Speed investment should only be used with an Adamant nature; a Jolly nature and maximum Speed investment can be used to increase the scope of things that Dragonite can outspeed after a Scale Shot; an example of a threat that Dragonite now outspeeds is Dragapult.

Choice Band.description:
• Extreme Speed is a priority move that hits the majority of the metagame for neutral damage, making it ideal to lock into.

  • Aerial Ace allows Dragonite to OHKO Pokemon like Urshifu-R, Rillaboom, and Amoongus without having to be lock into Outrage. Aqua Jet is secondary priority and allows it to double up with its partner on Ghost-types like Flutter Mane, and Ice Spinner allows it to remove Indeedee-F's Psychic Terrain while still having coverage for Pokemon like Rillaboom and Amoongus.

  • Outrage is used as its Dragon-type STAB move and allows it to OHKO almost the entire metagame.

  • Stomping Tantrum gives coverage into Steel-types like Kingambit and Archaludon.

  • The Speed EVs allow Dragonite to outspeed Dragapult in Tailwind, with the remaining EVs maximize its Attack and round out its bulk, allowing it to live attacks such as Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Dazzling Gleam

  • Normal is used as the Tera type, boosting Dragonite's Extreme Speed to stellar levels of power and removing its weaknesses to common Fairy- and Ice-type moves.

Typhlosion-Hisui.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Hisuian Typhlosion works best with Pokemon that help it attack before taking damage, which could weaken Eruption. Whimsicott and Galarian Weezing are two examples of this, with Whimsicott setting priority Tailwind and Galarian Weezing shutting down opposing Prankster Pokemon, something that pairs even better with Choice Scarf Hisuian Typhlosion, as it can outspeed and OHKO opposing Whimsicott. Redirection from Indeedee-F and Electabuzz helps Hisuian Typhlosion attack without having the Base Power of Eruption lowered, though it doesn't help against spread moves. Choice Specs is almost always paired with Prankster Tailwind support, mainly from Whimsicott, that allows Hisuian Typhlosion to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame. On the other hand, Choice Scarf is used on a variety of teams, as the Speed boost makes it less reliant on speed control.
  • The aforementioned Whimsicott and Galarian Weezing are good partners, but they don't have much of an offensive presence. More offensive Pokemon like Garchomp and Ursaluna-B can help mitigate this, threatening Kingambit and appreciating Hisuian Typhlosion's good matchup into Rillaboom.
  • Priority attacks like Kingambit's Sucker Punch can be a problem for Hisuian Typhlosion, as they weaken Eruption as well as threatening it for super effective damage. Indeedee-M can block priority attacks with Psychic Surge and threaten Incineroar, Kingambit, and Tyranitar, which Hisuian Typhlosion struggles with, with Tera Blast Fighting.

Strategy Comments

  • Hisuian Typhlosion is purely an offensive Pokemon, functioning best when one or both foes can be KOed by Eruption.
  • Hisuian Typhlosion works best as a lead, though it can also work as a late-game cleaner in matchups where the opponent has led with counters for it in previous games.
  • Hisuian Typhlosion struggles the most with specially defensive Pokemon like Assault Vest Kingambit and Pokemon that resist its Fire-type STAB moves like Incineroar. This can be mitigated by bringing Hisuian Typhlosion in the back or by using it to chip these Pokemon and clear the way for a partner late-game.

Glass Cannon.description:
• Hisuian Typhlosion has one job: spam powerful Fire-type moves.
  • Eruption is the main STAB attack of choice for Hisuian Typhlosion due to its high Base Power and spread damage, while Heat Wave can be used if Hisuian Typhlosion's health is lowered or at risk of being lowered by a foe's attack. Overheat gives Hisuian Typhlosion an option for single-target burst damage, letting it OHKO Porygon2 when paired with Tera Fire and Sunny Day support at the cost of being less spammable and often forcing a switch out. Overheat also bypasses Wide Guard, meaning that Hisuian Typhlosion can attack without having to play mindgames.
  • Choice Specs increases Hisuian Typhlosion's damage output, allowing it to OHKO Assault Vest Kingambit sets, while Choice Scarf lets it outspeed Dragapult and Sneasler.
  • Tera Fire maximizes the damage from Eruption, letting Choice Scarf sets OHKO Assault Vest Rillaboom and Choice Specs sets OHKO Archaludon and Porygon2 in sun.

Support.description:
Boasting excellent defenses and a plethora of utility moves, Umbreon finds itself a niche in providing bulky support along with Inner Focus ignoring the ever so common Fake Out from the likes of Incineroar and Rillaboom. Access to Foul Play allows Umbreon to tackle physical threats such as Calyrex-I as well as threatening Calyrex-S with a huge amount of damage. Snarl helps tremendously against special attackers like Terapagos, Calyrex-S, and Lunala, dealing a decent chunk of damage to the latter two. Helping Hand can also be used in this slot to further boost the team's offensive pressure to help secure KOs, such as Helping Hand-boosted Tera Fairy Zacian-C OHKOing Incineroar with Play Rough. Yawn is Umbreon's primary means of disruption, forcing the opponent to keep switching their Pokemon to prevent them from being put to sleep, while Taunt helps shut down opposing support Pokemon like Amoonguss or any Trick Room setters such as Farigiraf and Calyrex-I. Moonlight, on the other hand, increases Umbreon's longevity on the field and is especially useful in sun teams. Safety Goggles gives it a much needed immunity to Amoonguss, which can otherwise completely shut down Umbreon with Spore and Rage Powder. The EV spread allows Umbreon to survive a Collision Course from Koraidon outside weather, a Tera Fairy Moonblast from Flutter Mane, and prevents the 2HKO from a rain-boosted Weather Ball and Thunderbolt from Pelipper and a Special Attack Booster Energy Raging Bolt, respectively. Tera Water is an excellent defensive Tera type, further bolstering Umbreon against Calyrex-I, Kyogre, and Urshifu-R. On the other hand, Tera Poison provides a resistance to Fairy and Fighting-type moves such as Flutter Mane's Moonblast, Koraidon's Collision Course, and Urshifu's Close Combat.

Despite its longevity and disruptive options, Umbreon provides little to no offensive pressure most of the time. Pokemon like Zacian-C, Zamazenta-C, Koraidon, and the Urshifu formes instantly threaten Umbreon with their STAB moves, while faster Taunt users such as Incineroar and Flutter Mane shut down its support options. Umbreon pairs well with offensive Pokemon such as Zacian-C and Koraidon that can handle the aforementioned threats and take advantage of its Yawn pressure, with the latter setting up sun to maximize the healing provided by Moonlight. Rillaboom partners well with Umbreon because it functions as a Kyogre and Urshifu-R check while providing Grassy Terrain recovery and positioning through its U-turn. Meanwhile, Urshifu-R compliments Umbreon's support role by providing solid offensive pressure by pinning opponents with Surging Strikes, OHKOing Incineroar and Flutter Mane with the move.

Porygon2.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Thanks to its offensive and defensive tools, Porygon2 fits well on balance teams with a Trick Room mode. It benefits from teammates that provide utility, such as Fake Out or redirection, enabling it to set up Trick Room and go on the offensive, as well as teammates that can take advantage of Trick Room.
  • Porygon2 is most commonly paired with Incineroar, which offers Fake Out support to allow Porygon2 to set up Trick Room. It also provides Intimidate and Parting Shot utility, enhancing Porygon2’s survivability. Parting Shot is especially valuable, as it allows Incineroar to pivot to a Trick Room sweeper while Porygon2 sets up Trick Room. Additionally, Incineroar’s access to Flare Blitz and Knock Off helps to threaten Pokemon like Gholdengo, which would otherwise wall Porygon2.
  • The preferred Trick Room sweeper for Porygon2 teams is Ursaluna, as it takes full advantage of Trick Room by securing OHKOs on many Pokemon with its Guts boost. This pairing also works well because Porygon2 threatens special damage, while Ursaluna dishes out massive physical damage. Garchomp is another excellent offensive partner for Porygon2 because Garchomp provides a faster-paced, non-Trick Room-dependent offensive option for Porygon2 but with a less explosive damage output than Ursaluna.
  • Amoonguss is a common support partner for Porygon2, taking full advantage of Trick Room with its low Speed and putting foes to sleep with Spore to allow Porygon2 to attack unthreatened. It also provides Rage Powder redirection, enabling Porygon2 to set up Trick Room freely, and Pollen Puff to heal Porygon2, reducing the need for it to constantly use Recover.
  • Gholdengo is a common offensive partner for Porygon2, as it walls Pokemon like non-Throat Chop Sneasler, which can threaten massive damage to Porygon2, and Amoonguss, which can disrupt Porygon2 by putting it to sleep with Spore before it sets up Trick Room or deals much damage. Additionally, the threat of Nasty Plot boosts forces opponents to focus on Gholdengo, potentially allowing Porygon2 to move freely.
  • Flamigo and Sneasler are used on Porygon2 teams, as they threaten Incineroar, which can hinder Porygon2 with Knock Off and Parting Shot, as well as threats like Archaludon, Kingambit, and, in Flamigo's case, Gholdengo with Close Combat. Sneasler has the added benefit of threatening status with Dire Claw and Poison Touch, while Flamigo has Wide Guard utility to protect Porygon2 from moves like Eruption from Hisuian Typhlosion and Make It Rain from Gholdengo.

Strategy Comments

  • As a defensive unit with offensive potential, Porygon2 excels when it is minimally threatened by high-damage moves, such as Close Combat from Sneasler and Choice Specs Tera Fire Eruption from Hisuian Typhlosion. This necessitates pivoting and relying on its teammates to handle major damage dealers, enabling Porygon2 to safely set up Trick Room, heal itself as needed, and retaliate with substantial damage.
  • The optimal strategy for using Porygon2 involves pivoting between Pokemon like Incineroar and Amoonguss until Porygon2 and its partner sweepers like Ursaluna achieve a strong offensive position. This includes cycling Intimidate and Parting Shot with Incineroar to stack stat drops while using Amoonguss's Spore to stop opposing threats. By doing so, you create a window for Porygon2 and its offensive partners to safely attack and capitalize on the advantageous board state.
  • Due to Porygon2's relatively unoppressive presence, it's susceptible to being outpaced offensively, which is largely unavoidable. However, the best way to deal with this is by pivoting between teammates like Incineroar and Amoonguss to cycle Intimidate, use Spore, or provide redirection until Porygon2 and its offensive partner are in a favorable position. As mentioned earlier, Incineroar's Knock Off and Parting Shot significantly impair Porygon2's offensive and defensive capabilities, which is why Pokemon like Garchomp and Flamigo are employed to take down Incineroar. Additionally, cycling Fake Out from Incineroar and Rillaboom can be particularly threatening for Porygon2, as it may allow an opposing Pokemon to set up or chip away at Porygon2, potentially causing it to faint before it can use Recover. This is why Pokemon like Flamigo and Sneasler are often included, as they can threaten common Fake Out users as well as setup threats like Kingambit and Gholdengo.

Offensive Trick Room Setter.description:
• Porygon2’s primary role is to absorb hits, set up Trick Room, and exert offensive pressure while Trick Room is active. With Eviolite, Porygon2 becomes one of the bulkiest Pokemon in the format, and its access to Recover allows it to heal and remain difficult to remove. Additionally, the Download boost helps it gain more offensive pressure.
  • Tera Blast is essential to Porygon2's set, as it provides the necessary coverage to make Porygon2 offensively threatening once it's Terastallized. Ice Beam is also crucial, offering good coverage against Pokemon like Garchomp and Dragonite.
  • Tera Fighting is used for Fighting-type Tera Blast, enabling Porygon2 to deal significant damage to Steel- and Dark-type Pokemon such as Kingambit, Archaludon, and Incineroar. Tera Blast Ground also targets Steel-types but has the niche of threatening Pokemon like Electabuzz, Magmar, and Gholdengo. Tera Flying serves a slightly different purpose; while Flying-type Tera Blast is effective against threats like Rillaboom and Annihilape, it is primarily used for its resistance to Fighting-type moves and immunity to Ground-type attacks. This allows Porygon2's common partner, Ursaluna, to freely use Earthquake without worrying about hitting Porygon2.
  • With the provided Defense and HP investment, Porygon2 can almost always survive two Kowtow Cleaves from Black Glasses Tera Dark Kingambit, a Wave Crash from Tera Water Choice Band Basculegion-M in rain, and two Wood Hammers from most Assault Vest Rillaboom. The Special Defense investment allows it to live three Hyper Voices from Life Orb Primarina as well as a Make It Rain from Leftovers Gholdengo after two Nasty Plot boosts. The Special Attack investment ensures that Porygon2 can KO Garchomp with Ice Beam or with a Download-boosted Tera Blast Fighting or Ground if Garchomp has Terastallized into a Steel-type. With the Download boost, it also guarantees an OHKO on most Assault Vest Kingambit with Tera Blast Fighting and a 2HKO on non-Sitrus Berry Amoonguss with Ice Beam.

Offensive TR Setter.description:
• Tera Blast is used as strong Normal-type STAB move that offers coverage once Porygon2 Terastallizes. When Tera Blast is paired with a Download Attack boost, Tera Blast becomes a physical move when Porygon2 Terastallizes. This allows you to hit Assault Vest users like Raging Bolt and Rillaboom harder, as well as Pokemon with high base Special Defense such as Flutter Mane. Ice Beam is used as coverage against Landorus and Amoonguss, and Recover is used for longevity, allowing it to set Trick Room up multiple times.

  • With the bulk investment bolstered by the Eviolite, this Porygon2 always survives three Sacred Swords from Chien-Pao, Timid Choice Specs Chi-Yu Overheat, and two Moonblasts from Special Attack Booster Energy Flutter Mane. It also almost always lives a Sword of Ruin Close Combat from Adamant Urshifu.

  • Tera Poison is the main Tera type for Porygon2. It offers resistances to Grass-, Fighting-, and Fairy-type attacks, which are important against Rillaboom, Urshifu, and Flutter Mane, respectively, as well as offering a solid overall defensive typing. Additionally, it allows it to hit Grass- and Fairy-types like Rillaboom, Ogerpon-W, and Tera Fairy Flutter Mane for super effective damage with Tera Blast. Tera Fairy is used to wall Urshifu and hit it and Raging Bolt for super effective damage. Tera Flying is used to hit Grass- and Fighting-types like Urshifu, Ogerpon, and Rillaboom. Additionally, it makes Porygon2 immune to Earthquake from Ursaluna, giving its partner a valuable spread move. Finally, Tera Ghost is used for an immunity to Fighting-type attacks and Fake Out, as well as giving it the ability to hit Flutter Mane.

Support.description:
Smeargle's access to almost every move with Sketch grants it a great niche in Regulation G as a support Pokemon. Follow Me allows Smeargle to protect its more offensive partners, and Spore threatens to shut down opposing Pokemon, making it easier for Smeargle's partners to set up and sweep. Wide Guard blocks the plethora of spread moves in the metagame that ignore Smeargle's Follow Me, such as Tera Starstorm and Glacial Lance from Terapagos-S and Calyrex-I, respectively. This can, however, be replaced with Decorate on more offensive Calyrex-I teams, letting Trick Room threats like Calyrex-I and Ursaluna-B do significantly more damage quickly. Fake Out is the best last move on Smeargle, providing lots of pressure when it enters the field and opening up room for repositioning or setting up. Smeargle can use Spiky Shield over Fake Out for added longevity and to keep Focus Sash intact against opposing Fake Out. Transform can be used to utilize Smeargle as an offensive threat and win condition, especially when transforming into partner Calyrex-S or opposing Restricted Pokemon. Smeargle requires Focus Sash to make up for its horrendous bulk. Smeargle can also opt for an EV spread of 252 HP / 252 Def with a Relaxed nature and 0 Speed IVs on Trick Room teams, enabling Smeargle to boost its partners with Decorate before they attack. Moody is the primary ability on Smeargle, as it has a good chance of allowing Smeargle to take more attacks or threaten fast Spore. Calyrex-I teams can utilize Own Tempo to make sure Smeargle is always slow to function under Trick Room. Smeargle prefers Tera Ghost to escape Fake Out, but it may use Tera Grass on a team with Farigiraf for the immunity to Spore and Rage Powder from Amoonguss, as well as the resistance to Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes, which would otherwise OHKO it through Focus Sash.

Smeargle struggles due to its lack of offensive pressure as a full support Pokemon. This makes it incredibly vulnerable to Taunt from Pokemon like Tornadus and Incineroar. Smeargle also lacks longevity, even with Focus Sash, so its chances to support its allies are limited. Hence, Smeargle is strongest with incredibly offensive Restricted Pokemon like the Calyrex formes. Smeargle's Follow Me and Fake Out helps the Calyrex formes set up Nasty Plot and Trick Room, respectively. Smeargle also protects them with Wide Guard from opposing Calyrex-S and Kyogre, which can otherwise threaten major damage if not an OHKO. These teams will usually carry Urshifu-R and Ursaluna-B to threaten Incineroar. The two also appreciate Smeargle's support as some of the most oppressive non-Restricted Pokemon available. Farigiraf can pair with Smeargle on hyper offensive Calyrex-I teams to form a strong Trick Room core and enable Smeargle to utilize Tera Grass without fear of Fake Out and Prankster Taunt.

Choice Band.description:
Entei fulfills the role of a powerful sweeper, using its high Attack in tandem with Choice Band and an Intimidate and Fake Out immunity to become a powerful offensive threat that can easily weaken or clean up teams with Extreme Speed and Sacred Fire. Flare Blitz can be used as a more powerful and accurate alternative to Sacred Fire, allowing Entei to OHKO Calyrex-I and defensive Flutter Mane. Its coverage includes Stomping Tantrum, which can help it hit Incineroar and Tera Fire Pokemon such as Calyrex-I whilst additionally allowing Entei to hit Electric-types such as Miraidon for heavy damage, and Stone Edge, which is used for hitting Flying-types such as Pelipper and threatening Fire-types, namely the Ground-neutral Ogerpon-H, whilst being naturally stronger then Stomping Tantrum. Choice Band bolsters Entei's physical power significantly, guaranteeing an OHKO on Calyrex-I with Sacred Fire in tandem with Chien-Pao's Sword of Ruin and giving Extreme Speed a high chance to OHKO defensively invested Chi-Yu when bolstered by Sword of Ruin and Tera Normal. The HP and Special Defense investment allows Entei to play more flexibly against special attackers, increasing its ability to take on the likes of Calyrex-S, most notably allowing it to always survive Astral Barrage from Choice Specs Calyrex-S and Electro Drift from Choice Specs Miraidon out of Electric Terrain. However, running maximum Attack investment allows Entei to maximize its damage output without hindering its natural bulk significantly. Tera Normal boosts Entei's Extreme Speed significantly, allowing it to pick up OHKOs on Tornadus and Landorus-I with Sword of Ruin and 2HKOs on Urshifu-R and Kyogre whilst providing defensive utility in removing Entei's weaknesses to Water-, Ground-, and Rock-type attacks, namely Surging Strikes from Urshifu-R, Earth Power from Landorus-I, and Ivy Cudgel from Ogerpon-C, and notably allowing it an immunity to Astral Barrage from Calyrex-S.

Entei, whilst being a powerful offensive threat, does struggle with many metagame threats, namely powerful Water-types in Urshifu-R and Kyogre, which can tank Entei's attacks easily and KO back; Raging Bolt, which can easily survive the majority of its moves and threaten back with heavy damage; and Landorus, which can threaten it with Ground-type STAB moves whilst utilizing Tera Ghost to avoid Extreme Speed. Additionally, Entei can struggle with being locked into moves by Choice Band, so foes like Incineroar and Pelipper and faster offensive Pokemon like Miraidon can take advantage of it being locked into its Fire-type STAB moves, whilst Ghost-types such as Calyrex-S can benefit if Entei locks into Extreme Speed. Additionally, Entei's reliance on a priority move for its damage output can lead to it struggling greatly against priority-blocking effects from the likes of Indeedee-F and Farigiraf. Entei partners particularly well with Chien-Pao, as it can assist Entei in wallbreaking through increasing Entei's damage output with Sword of Ruin and threaten the Ghost-types that can take advantage of Entei as well as Landorus, Miraidon, Farigiraf, and Indeedee-F, whilst Entei in turn threatens Chien-Pao's counters, namely Chi-Yu. Other great partners for Entei include Rillaboom, which provides Fake Out support for Entei whilst also providing Terrain control that can help against Miraidon and Indeedee-F, and Flutter Mane, which can control the speed of the battle and also threatens Miraidon, and both can threaten Entei's main answer in Urshifu-R. The Restricted Pokemon Entei is most commonly partnered with is Zamazenta-C, as Zamazenta-C threatens Entei's potential answers, such as Incineroar and Ogerpon-C, and Entei can chip some of its common checks, namely Landorus, whilst being able to threaten Ogerpon-H and Chi-Yu, which can assist Zamazenta-C greatly.

Bulky Attacker.description:
• Snarl slows down strong special attackers such as Flutter Mane, Raging Bolt, and Iron Crown. Tera Blast can be used instead when using Tera Grass to hit Water-types.

  • Assault Vest helps increase Entei's longevity against special attackers such as Flutter Mane, making Entei even harder to remove taking into account Sacred Fire's burn chance.

  • The EV spread allows Entei to survive a 116 Special Attack Modest Earth Power from Landorus and, when Terastallized, almost always survive Mystic Water Urshifu-R's Tera Water-boosted Surging Strikes, the rest of the EVs are used to maximize its damage output.

  • Tera Grass provides resistances to Water- and Ground- types like Urshifu-R and Landorus, as well as granting a Spore immunity. Tera Normal boosts Entei's Extreme Speed power while also removing its original weaknesses.

Bulky Support.description:
With exceptional bulk, a great defensive typing, and Inner Focus allowing it to ignore Fake Out from the likes of Incineroar and Rillaboom, Suicune provides bulky support options thanks to its plethora of utility and disruptive moves. Snarl weakens special attackers like Calyrex-S, Terapagos, and Kyogre. Tailwind provides speed control for the team, while Mist finds a niche in protecting the team from stat drops, such as from Intimidate and Snarl. Roar allows Suicune to prevent Trick Room from going up by forcefully switching out setters like Farigiraf and Calyrex-I and can neutralize setup attempts from Pokemon like Calm Mind Terapagos while tanking attacks like Glacial Lance and Tera Starstorm thanks to its excellent defenses. Meanwhile, Helping Hand boosts the partner Pokemon's damage output to quickly KO opposing Pokemon. Icy Wind is a nice alternative in this slot for a lingering Speed reduction, which can come in handy when facing Calyrex-S and Zacian-C. Safety Goggles grants an immunity to Spore and Rage Powder and is especially useful to force out Trick Room setters with Roar while ignoring Amoonguss. Leftovers, on the other hand, provides passive recovery to further increase Suicune's longevity when combined with its natural bulk. The EV spread allows Suicune to avoid a 3HKO from -1 Choice Specs Terapagos's and Calyrex I's Tera Starstorm and High Horsepower, respectively, and turns Koraidon's Collision Course into a 3HKO after Leftovers recovery. The Special Defense EVs let Suicune survive two Astral Barrages from +1 bulky Calyrex-S. The Speed investment enables Suicune to outspeed most Rillaboom, helping it set up Tailwind before Rillaboom can hit it with a Wood Hammer. Tera Dark provides a resistance to Ghost-type attacks like Calyrex-S's Astral Barrage, an immunity to its Psyshock, and an immunity to Prankster Taunt from Tornadus and Whimsicott, and it also enables Suicune to 2HKO Calyrex-S with Snarl.

Due to its passive field presence, Suicune is immediately threatened by strong super effective attacks like Volt Switch and Electro Drift from Miraidon, Thunderbolt from Raging Bolt, and Wood Hammer from Rillaboom. Pokemon carrying Covert Cloak, like Calyrex-S and Terapagos, can simply choose to ignore Suicune and set up. Prankster Taunt users like Tornadus can shut down most of Suicune's support options as well, unless it Terastallizes. This makes fast offensive Pokemon like Zacian-C excellent partners for Suicune, as they outspeed and threaten to OHKO most of the aforementioned Pokemon while appreciating the protection against stat drops provided by Suicune's Mist. Landorus counters threatening Electric-types like Miraidon and Raging Bolt and deals massive damage to Rillaboom with Sludge Bomb. Incineroar provides Fake Out and Intimidate support, gets rid of Covert Cloak with Knock Off, and threatens to burn Rillaboom with Will-O-Wisp.

Tyranitar.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Tyranitar excels at complementing powerhouses like Gholdengo by checking its threats such as Kingambit, Incineroar, and Hisuian Typhlosion, as well as disrupting weather-reliant Pokemon like Pelipper and Archaludon. Tyranitar appreciates redirection support like Amoonguss and Magmar to handle Fighting-type attacks like Close Combat from Sneasler and works well with Trick Room balance composition due to its mediocre Speed tier.
  • Tyranitar and Gholdengo complement each other, with Gholdengo checking threats such as Rillaboom, Amoonguss, and Archaludon in sand while appreciating Tyranitar's coverage options that handle Fire-types such as Volcarona, Talonflame, and Incineroar that Gholdengo is weak to. Amoonguss is an exceptional support option, redirecting Fighting-type attacks like Close Combat and Drain Punch from Sneasler and Annihilape, respectively. Due to its average Speed tier, Tyranitar excels in both Tailwind and Trick Room. Trick Room setters such as Porygon2 and Sinistcha allow Amoonguss and Tyranitar to take advantage of their lower Speed stat to move before their foes. Meanwhile, Talonflame provides Tailwind to help Tyranitar and its faster partners like Gholdengo move first. Rillaboom checks troublesome Water-types like Basculegion and Primarina while weakening Garchomp's Earthquake and offering passive recovery thanks to its Grassy Terrain.
  • Tyranitar is especially susceptible to Garchomp and Archaludon, lacking the means to outdamage them while being weak to their coverage options like the latter's Body Press. Tera Steel Gholdengo threatens to 2HKO Tyranitar with Make it Rain, while faster physical attackers like Basculegion and Rillaboom check it. Redirectors like Amoonguss help to an extent, while speed control in the form of Trick Room can help turn the tide of the battle. Offensive partners like Garchomp check Archaludon and Gholdengo with Stomping Tantrum and Earthquake, while Primarina threatens Garchomp with Moonblast.

Strategy Comments

  • As a weather setter and special tank, Tyranitar excels at threatening checks to powerhouses like Gholdengo and Garchomp, weakening opposing weather teams such as rain and sun, as well as checking hard Trick Room teams utilizing Armarouge, Torkoal, and Indeedee-F. Tyranitar also immediately threatens offensive Pokemon such as Choice Specs Hisuian Typhlosion or Talonflame and can fill the role of a strong defensive backbone of the team.
  • Tyranitar is a strong lead into offensive strategies, ideally to get rid of Talonflame or Hisuian Typhlosion to help its partners like Gholdengo for late-game dominance. Against rain teams, a well-timed switch-in can force Archaludon to waste a turn charging its Electro Shot while threatening Pelipper with Rock Slide. Additionally, setting up sand early can be useful in breaking Focus Sash on common metagame threats such as Sneasler. Tyranitar's efficiency increases with the help of speed control like Trick Room, often provided by Porygon2, where it is safe to move first and secure KOs.
  • Gholdengo, Annihilape, Archaludon, and Garchomp threaten to either OHKO or deal a massive amount of damage to Tyranitar with their STAB moves. It is advisable to keep Tyranitar in the back until the threat is removed or disrupted, either via support options like Amoonguss and Incineroar or by utilizing offensive Pokemon like Volcarona, Gholdengo, and Garchomp.

Sand Tank.description:
• Boasting excellent defenses and a powerful Attack stat with decent coverage options, Tyranitar functions as a weather-setting tank thanks to its ability, checking meta threats such as Pelipper, Volcarona, and Kingambit.
  • Tera Blast Flying allows Tyranitar to hit Sneasler, Rillaboom, and Amoonguss super effectively, while Low Kick deals massive damage to Hydreigon and OHKOes Kingambit and opposing Tyranitar.
  • Assault Vest further amplifies Tyranitar Special Defense, working in tandem with sand to bolster its special bulk to enormous proportions.
  • Tera Flying sheds Tyranitar's weaknesses to Fighting- and Ground-type attacks like Sneasler's Close Combat and Garchomp's Earthquake while providing additional coverage in the form of Tera Blast to hit Fighting-types like Sneasler and Grass-types like Rillaboom, Amoonguss, and Tera Grass Archaludon.
  • The Speed EVs help outspeed Sneasler in Tailwind while still having sufficient bulk to withstand Choice Specs Tera Steel Make it Rain from Gholdengo comfortably.

Offensive Weather Support.description:
Pelipper's access to Drizzle and Wide Guard in a metagame full of spread moves and weather control allow it to thrive as a support Pokemon with the threat of strong STAB options. Wide Guard is an excellent utility move, which not only protects its partner but, along with Pelipper's typing, also allows it to counter many Restricted Pokemon such as Groudon, Koraidon, both Calyrex formes, and Kyogre. Weather Ball and Hurricane's high Base Power make up for Pelipper's middling Special Attack, nuking most targets weak to its STAB moves, such as both Urshifu formes and Incineroar. Protect is generally preferred for utility and to block Fake Out, but Helping Hand can be used to support its teammates, thanks to moving before Fake Out. Focus Sash is needed to guarantee Pelipper can remain a threat even when facing one of the many Pokemon that can hit it for super effective damage. Tera Ghost is a generally strong Tera type and allows Pelipper to dodge Fake Out, which is especially important because it threatens to break Focus Sash. Tera Stellar is also viable to boost Pelipper's damage.

Any Pokemon that benefits from rain or Wide Guard appreciates Pelipper's support. Calyrex-I, Zacian-C, and Urshifu-R all value Pelipper's support, with Wide Guard blocking super effective Astral Barrages and Precipice Blades and rain boosting Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes. Other support Pokemon like Amoonguss and Incineroar are also strong with Pelipper defensively, with it handling threats such as Urshifu-R and Landorus for Incineroar and Wide Guard blocking Bleakwind Storms from hitting Amoonguss. Its low Speed tier means it's essentially useless against Pokemon that can exploit its Speed and bring it down to its Focus Sash, leaving Pelipper unable to do anything without the threat of being knocked out. Opposing weather also completely cripples Pelipper, as its moves rely on rain to be consistent; however, its lower Speed compared to most weather setters means this scenario is playable, with rain more commonly lasting its five turns. Fake Out and other priority moves that can break Focus Sash easily are also devastating.

Bulky Support.description:
With a good set of supportive moves like Wide Guard to protect against damaging spread moves and a typing that can check various Pokemon in the metagame like Zamazenta-C and Urshifu-R, Pelipper can be a good supportive option for a team. Pelipper's ability Drizzle is also very important, as rain allows it to check threats such as Koraidon. Weather Ball and Hurricane are great STAB moves to have, as they benefit from rain and remove Pokemon like Incineroar and Urshifu-R. Protect is helpful for blocking Fake Out; Helping Hand supports Pelipper's teammates and lets them to dish out huge damage; and Tailwind provides speed control for Pelipper and its teammates. Rocky Helmet punishes Urshifu-R while also being helpful for chip damage, breaking Focus Sash held by Pokemon like Mienshao and Chien-Pao. Safety Goggles provides an immunity to Spore and Rage Powder from Amoonguss, and Covert Cloak gives Pelipper an immunity to Fake Out flinches from Incineroar and Rillaboom. The EV spread allows Pelipper to outspeed the Ogerpon formes under Tailwind and survive a Wood Hammer from Rillaboom or a Moonblast from Choice Specs Flutter Mane. The Special Attack investment is used to OHKO Incineroar and Groudon under rain. Tera Ghost gives Pelipper an immunity to Fake Out, while Tera Grass is a good defensive Tera type that lets it resist Electric- and Grass-type moves like Wood Hammer and Volt Switch while also gaining an immunity to powder moves like Spore and Rage Powder. Tera Dark makes Pelipper immune to Prankster Taunt from Whimsicott and Tornadus and resists Astral Barrage from Calyrex-S.

Raging Bolt and Miraidon are great counters to Pelipper, as they resist its STAB moves and can OHKO with Volt Switch or Thunderbolt. Ogerpon-C can also check Pelipper with its super effective Ivy Cudgel while also not worrying about Rocky Helmet sets breaking its Sturdy ability. Other forms of weather, like sun, can be devastating for Pelipper, since its two attacking moves are reliant on rain. Zamazenta-C and Calyrex-I like Pelipper's Wide Guard support blocking moves like Astral Barrage and Tera Starstorm, while Urshifu-R appreciates rain boosting its Water-type moves. Pelipper forms a good defensive core with Incineroar, Rillaboom, and Amoonguss, which resist Grass- and Electric-type moves, while Pelipper damages threats like Urshifu-R.

Weather Setter.description:
• Pelipper functions as a weather setter thanks to Drizzle, enabling powerhouses like Archaludon and Basculegion-M to dish out enormous damage as well as providing support in the form of speed control or Wide Guard. Its Flying- and Water-type STAB options combined with its decent Speed help Pelipper to fill in the role of an attacker as well, taking advantage of its own rain to buff its offensive options.
  • Weather Ball is a flexible attack that gains a STAB boost in rain while providing decent coverage under opposing weather like sun. Tailwind provides speed control for the team, whereas Wide Guard protects the team from Gholdengo's Make it Rain, Ursaluna-B's Hyper Voice, Expanding Force in Psychic Terrain, and Garchomp's Earthquake.
  • Focus Sash allows Pelipper to survive an attack due to the set's frailty, increasing its long-term value as a weather setter and allowing it to get an extra attack off.
  • Tera Stellar further boosts its damage, allowing Pelipper to OHKO Amoonguss and Annihilape with Hurricane and Tera Normal Ursaluna-B and Assault Vest Incineroar with rain-boosted Weather Ball. Meanwhile, Tera Ghost provides an immunity to Fake Out, enabling an early Tailwind uninterrupted while keeping Focus Sash intact.
  • A maximized Special Attack stat with a Modest nature secures an OHKO on Incineroar with rain-boosted Weather Ball and on Amoonguss with Tera Stellar Hurricane, while a Timid nature can be opted for faster speed control and securing KOs on weakened Pokemon, and it comes in handy in rain mirror matches.

Rain Setter.description:
• Pelipper can use Wide Guard over Protect to block spread move, most notably Iron Crown's Expanding Force. Pelipper utilizes Weather Ball to obtain strong boosted STAB, threatening Incineroar and Landorus.

  • Pelipper utilizes Rocky Helmet to provide useful chip damage against Fake Out users, Ice Spinner Chien-Pao, and Urshifu-R, but can use Focus Sash for survivability or Damp Rock to extend rain for slower teams.

  • When using Focus Sash, Pelipper should use an alternative spread of 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with a Modest or Timid nature instead, foregoing bulk.

  • The EV spread helps Pelipper survive a Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Moonblast and almost always a Miracle Seed Rillaboom's Wood Hammer. The Speed investment allows Pelipper to outspeed Ogerpon when in Tailwind.

  • Tera Steel helps Pelipper gain resistances to strong threats like Rillaboom and Flutter Mane, giving it a turn to set Tailwind or click Hurricane. Tera Flying can be used to boost Pelipper's damage output and, when fully invested in Special Attack, threaten Amoonguss for an OHKO. Tera Ghost makes Pelipper immune to common moves, being Fake Out and Extreme Speed.

Torkoal.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Torkoal performs best at supporting a variety of Pokemon thanks to its sun-setting capabilities. Torkoal additionally functions well as a powerful sweeper when its partners set up Trick Room.
  • When used as a supportive sun setter, Torkoal is often paired with Jumpluff, which takes advantage of the sun via Chlorophyll, allowing it to set Tailwind or put foes to sleep with Sleep Powder before they can move. Torkoal boosts the power of its partners' Fire-type attacks like Heat Wave and Eruption with the sun, making it a great pairing alongside Charizard and Hisuian Typhlosion. Charizard gains an additional damage boost from the sun thanks to Solar Power.
  • Offensive Torkoal pairs well with reliable bulky Trick Room setters like Hatterene and Indeedee-F. Hatterene is capable of providing additional special offense with its powerful Dazzling Gleam as well as Expanding Force when paired with Indeedee-F. Indeedee-F on the other hand provides redirection and can boost Torkoal's damage with Helping Hand as well as using Heal Pulse to provide healing, mitigating the damage reduction of Eruption and increasing Torkoal's longevity. Indeedee-F's Psychic Terrain protects Torkoal from priority attacks, ensuring Torkoal can deal maximum damage with Eruption. Other offensive Trick Room-reliant partners like Ursaluna and Gallade pair well with Torkoal by threatening devastating physical damage. Ursaluna threatens specially defensive foes like Tyranitar. Meanwhile, Gallade deals with bulky foes Torkoal struggles to damage like Incineroar and Annihilape. Gallade additionally protects Torkoal from threatening spread attacks like Earthquake with Wide Guard.
  • Supportive Torkoal can be very passive with Overheat as its primary offensive attack. It is very reliant on enabling its partners to take the KOs it can't achieve alone. Offensive Torkoal struggles to sufficiently damage Water-types like Primarina, so it relies on partners like Hatterene and Ursaluna to defeat them. Torkoal is easily threatened by powerful sweepers that move before Torkoal and threaten super effective damage like Garchomp and Tyranitar. Hatterene can set up Trick Room to ensure they do not attack before Torkoal moves and threatens both of them with its Fairy-type attacks.

Strategy Comments

  • Supportive Torkoal is best positioned when it can easily enable sun and provide support for its partners. Offensive Torkoal, on the other hand, is best used to sweep once Trick Room is active.
  • As a supportive sun setter, Torkoal should be lead to set sun immediately for its partners. When it is lead, this set can potentially switch out immediately after Intimidate from Incineroar is triggered, allowing an offensive partner like Hisuian Typhlosion to switch in safely before you and the opponent can select their attacks for the turn. When using an offensive set, Torkoal is best kept in the back and should only be switched in while Trick Room is active.
  • Foes capable of KOing Torkoal and its Trick Room-setting partners before Trick Room is set up are huge threats. To mitigate this, Indeedee-F can redirect attacks to protect Torkoal or the Trick Room setter from damage. Rain setters like Pelipper override the sun set by Torkoal, weakening and disrupting its partners; to prevent this, the rain setters should be KOed as soon as possible.

Supportive Sun Setter.description:
• This Torkoal set is used for setting up sun and providing additional support for its partners.
  • Overheat is a powerful nuke that allows Torkoal to switch out immediately after use thanks to Eject Pack. Eruption deals strong spread damage if Torkoal stays on the field. Clear Smog clears foes' stat boosts, most notably from Dondozo.
  • Eject Pack allows Torkoal to switch out on lead when it has its Attack dropped by Intimidate from Incineroar, allowing its partners to take advantage of the sun immediately, as well as using Overheat to allow a partner to switch in safely and at the end of the turn.
  • Tera Fire allows Torkoal to OHKO Ursaluna-B with Overheat.

Trick Room Sweeper.description:
• Torkoal is a threatening sweeper under Trick Room that sets up sun, providing support for its partners.
  • Eruption deals powerful Fire-type spread damage; meanwhile, Heat Wave provides consistent spread damage regardless of Torkoal's remaining HP. Weather Ball deals strong, consistent damage while sun is active, and Overheat is often used as a single-use nuke attack. Earth Power allows Torkoal to threaten Fire-types like Incineroar. Protect is used on Charcoal sets, while Clear Smog is used on Choice Specs sets to disrupt Dondozo and setup sweepers like Volcarona.
  • Charcoal and Choice Specs are used to increase Torkoal's damage, with Charcoal guaranteeing Eruption OHKOes Assault Vest Rillaboom and Choice Specs Weather Ball 2HKOing Assault Vest Archaludon.
  • Tera Fire boosts Torkoal's damage, allowing it to OHKO Ursaluna with Eruption.

Metagross.overview:
• Metagross serves as a good defensive Pokemon on balance teams thanks to its great defenses that are bolstered even further by Assault Vest, its good ability, and its nice defensive typing against foes like Raging Bolt and Iron Crown. Its access to coverage and high Attack stat make it appreciated as an offensive threat too.

  • Metagross can pair well with offensive Pokemon like Flutter Mane and Landorus, which can help deal with the Dark-, Ghost-, and Fire-types that threaten it like Urshifu-S, Gholdengo, and Entei. Another excellent partner can be Ogerpon-W, which has great synergy with Metagross, being able to deal with Ground-types like Landorus and redirect Sucker Punch from Chien-Pao, while Metagross can help Ogerpon-W against Rillaboom and Raging Bolt.

  • Before Terastallizing, Metagross can be overwhelmed by Pokemon like Kingambit, Chi-Yu, and Entei, making defensive partners like Amoonguss and Incineroar appreciated. Rillaboom can also be a good teammate for Metagross, providing it with passive recovery and utility via Grassy Terrain and Fake Out, respectively.

Bulky Attacker.description:
• Stomping Tantrum lets Metagross hit Fire- and Steel-types likeIncineroar, Entei, and Kingambit and can also help against targets like Raging Bolt. Stomping Tantrum in particular is important to hit Steel-types like Iron Crown, as they wall Metagross's STAB moves.

  • Bullet Punch can be used to help pick off weakened foes like Flutter Mane.

  • With an Assault Vest, Metagross can almost always survive Earth Power from Landorus

  • With the given EV spread, Metagross almost always survives Icicle Crash from Adamant Chien-Pao when using Tera Dragon, and it is only 3HKOed by -1 Adamant Chien-Pao's Sacred Sword when using Tera Steel. The Speed EVs let it outspeed -1 Adamant Landorus-T, as well as Roaring Moon and Adamant Chien-Pao when in Tailwind.

  • Tera Dragon lets Metagross handle Fire-types like Chi-Yu and Entei in a pinch, and it can also be useful to deal with Water-types like Ogerpon-W and Choice Scarf Urshifu-R. Tera Steel helps remove its weakness against Pokemon like Kingambit, Flutter Mane, and Chien-Pao, and it can also give Bullet Punch a chance to OHKO offensive Flutter Mane.

Registeel.overview:
• With an extremely high Defense stat and access to the coveted IronPress combination, Registeel serves the role of the format's late-game sweeper. Steel is an incredibly good typing defensively, and Clear Body stops Intimidate from the likes of Incineroar, which could otherwise prevent the OHKO on Flutter Mane with Heavy Slam.

  • Registeel fits best on balance teams that feature its favorite partners. Incineroar and Amoonguss can slow down the pace of the game, Latias provides crucial speed control in Tailwind, and Rillaboom's Grassy Surge and Fake Out is appreciated by Registeel. Additionally, Latias and Rillaboom threaten Urshifu-R. Similarly, Raging Bolt is also a good Registeel partner, being the premier Urshifu-R counter in the format.

  • Notable good matchups for Registeel include Rillaboom and Ogerpon-W, both of which get cleanly 2HKOed by Body Press after a single Iron Defense boost. Kingambit also does poorly against Registeel, as Swords Dance can be mitigated by Iron Defense and Body Press hits Kingambit very hard if it does not Terastallize.

  • However, not all physical attackers are helpless against the IronPress Registeel. Both Urshifu formes can pose a threat, depending on Registeel's choice of Tera type. Chien-Pao can threaten heavy damage with Sacred Sword if Registeel has not used Terastallization. Gholdengo is also a hard counter to Registeel, as it is immune to Body Press and resists Heavy Slam while also being able to set up with Nasty Plot and break through Registeel's high bulk.

IronPress.description:
• Heavy Slam allows Registeel to hit opposing Ghost-types like Flutter Mane. 52 Attack EVs allow Heavy Slam to OHKO bulky Flutter Mane.

  • Leftovers keeps it healthy throughout the game, with Protect providing additional turns of recovery.

  • Tera Water is the standard Tera Type for Registeel, allowing it to resist Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes and being a generally good defensive typing.
